DOCNAME: CASE OF GALLARDO SANCHEZ v. ITALY
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 5 - Right to liberty and security (Article 5-1 - Deprivation of liberty;Lawful arrest or detention;Article 5-1-f - Extradition)
JUDGES: George Nicolaou;Guido Raimondi;Krzysztof Wojtyczek;Ledi Bianku;Nona Tsotsoria;Päivi Hirvelä;Paul Mahoney
TEXT: CARDINAL . The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
CARDINAL . The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE ( GPE ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE , the applicant , who had been accused of arson by the NORP authorities , was taken into custody pending extradition by the GPE police on the basis of an arrest warrant issued by ORG on DATE under LAW DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of L’Aquila validated the applicant ’s arrest and ordered his detention .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG asked ORG to extend his detention .

CARDINAL . At the hearing of DATE , the President of ORG , ruling under LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , established the applicant ’s identity and asked if he gave his consent to his extradition . He did not consent .
CARDINAL . NORP On DATE the Minister of ORG informed ORG that , on DATE , the NORP authorities had sent a request for extradition together with all the requisite supporting documents .
CARDINAL . On DATE the public prosecutor ’s office asked ORG to grant the extradition request .
CARDINAL . The hearing was scheduled for DATE . At the request of the applicant ’s representative , it was postponed until DATE .

CARDINAL . Without any prior investigation ORG approved the extradition by a decision of DATE , deposited on DATE . It verified the conformity of the extradition request with ORG and compliance with the ne bis in idem and double criminality principles , and it ruled out the possibility that the proceedings had been brought for any discriminatory or political reasons .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant appealed on points of law , arguing in particular that the request for his extradition had been sent by the NORP authorities after DATE time - limit provided for in LAW , which meant in his view that his detention had been unlawful . He further argued that the charges laid against him by the NORP authorities were not based on serious indications of guilt . He submitted that he should therefore be released .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE , deposited in the registry on DATE , ORG dismissed the appeal with CARDINAL page of reasoning , in particular because it found that the extradition request had been received within the time - limit provided for in LAW and that it did not have jurisdiction to examine whether serious indications of guilt had been adduced .

CARDINAL . In the meantime , on CARDINAL occasions DATE , the applicant had applied to ORG , unsuccessfully , to obtain his release . In its last decision of DATE , adopted in private in compliance with the adversarial principle , and without any prior investigation , ORG found that there was no reason to depart from the CARDINAL previous rejection decisions , having regard to the on - going risk that the applicant might abscond , even though the authorities had taken away his passport , and to the ORG ’s obligation to comply with its international commitments .
CARDINAL . On DATE the Minister of ORG signed the extradition order .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was extradited to GPE .
